climbs.name: Worry Wart
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Blake Summers, 27 August 2012

content.description:
Standing at the same belay spot as for Fret Arête, climb the short little thin crack with numerous knobs (warts) on the featured steep face to where the angle decreases and the crack continues to the shared two-bolt belay with Scream Seam.

Super Fun and a great place to hide from the heat for enough short climbs to keep your attention for an evening escape.
content.protection: Aliens or TCUs or C3s and small Nuts to a two-bolt belay.
content.location: Worry Wart shares the anchors with Scream Seam and is another thin anxiety ridden crack just around the corner to the right.

content.description: Crux is the final move.  Good moves.  Needs cleaned more.
content.location: The route is lookers right of Twinkie's Hatchet.  It is easily walked off.

content.description: Three bolts up the compact granite to a two bolt chain anchor.  Great rock and fun edging, but short, of course.
content.location: Just to the left of Mary's Mustache.

content.description:
Unknown route name and FA. If anyone knows, let me know.

Start out face climbing to gain a small tips crack. Use the crack and face holds to climb up to the splitter finger crack 2/3's from the top.

I'd put this route around 10d.  This is the best route at the cliff in my opinion.
content.protection: Bring the small stuff (RPs, Micros, offset brassies).
content.location: This is a nice looking crack to the right of the bolted aid route in the middle of the cliff band directly above the girl scout camp. Obvious anchors at the top make this route easy to find.

content.description: Hard start to scramble to awkward hand crack.  Crux is at the top.
content.protection: Standard rack w/large cams, small nuts
content.location: The route is located in the west side of Twinkies Hatchet at the apex of the gully.  At this time, descend by walking over to the anchors of Rusty Blade.

content.description: Climb the black chimney with the old piton, mantle out onto the first ledge, climb over the grass in the flake straight above, then climb the 10 foot splitter hand crack to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack with some micro nuts
content.location: Located to the right at the top of the Frighton Gully, the feature looks like a hatchet and has a perfect crack on the top left side. Feature is visible on the right of the Fret Aret Photo.

climbs.name: Scream Seam
climbs.fa: Blake Summers and James Garrett, August 2012

content.description:
More good stuff just to the left (3m left and below) of Fret Arête. Again, like the other routes in this area, one wishes only that they would last a little longer. The stone is very good sculpted alpine granite.

Pitch #1: Climb up the thin layback crack to a shelf mantle and then move right to a two-bolt anchor. Rappel the short pitch.
content.protection: Small Nuts, Aliens, and C3s to a two-bolt belay.
content.location:
Shorter than Fret Arête!! which is 4m to the right. Good fun none the less on these cluster of short climbs in short proximity on excellent rock in the cool air at elevation above Brighton.

As for the other routes, hike past the Brighton Girls Scout Camp and up the boulder field to the wall. To the east of the boulder field, a faint steep trail through the woods passes numerous camp fire areas and leads to the boulder field up higher.

content.description: Crux is below roof.  Super fun.  Has it all.
content.protection: standard rack w/small cams and micro nuts.  Rap off two ring anchors above the roof.
content.location: Route is lookers left of the apex of The Brighton's Frighten Wall.  Climbs the obvious orange streak.

content.description: Mary's Mustache could have been a classic only if it were 30 feet taller. Regardless its still one of the best routes in the area with fun movement and good protection. Sling a horn, then climb a short fingertips crack that transitions into a perfect hand sized crack towards the top. Lots of options for building an anchor at the top of the hand crack. When ready to rap, climb up and right about 15 feet to bolts above the offwidth flake to the right.
content.protection: Trad Gear, Sling around a solid block or hand sized cams for the anchor. Climb up and right from the top for rappel anchors above the route to the right.
content.location: The route starts over by magic flake. It starts 15 yards east of Magic flake situated between a large scary detached flake and the unknown sport route. Look for the fingertip crack.

climbs.name: Fret Arête
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Matt Washburn, 5 July 2012

content.description:
Once you scramble to the base of the Frighton Wall, an obvious line appears that ascends a striking edge of beautiful alpine granite. Consider bringing mosquito repellant.

Pitch #1: Very technical initial moves climb the granite edge with unique footholds on the left and finger locks on the right. It steepens but nice overlaps allow a few dynamic moves to the two-bolt belay. 5.9+ or 10.a (?), 20m.

MF starts in a somewhat steep fingers to hands crack that takes tons of gear and reveals cool moves. Use the positive and solid flake at the top to pull the bulge. There are no chains at the top; set a natural anchor to lower or TR. You can breakdown the anchor and walk down a short gully back to the base.
content.protection: .5 to #3 Camalots and quickdraws. The top anchor will take a .3 and .4 Camalots and slings.
content.location: This climb is located in the next gully to the east of the other climbs on the Brighton Frighton wall. Approach as normal to the Brighton Frighton wall passing by the girls camp to the boulder field. Head east instead of west up into the main gulley. This climb has a landmark 'magic' flake near the top.

climbs.name: Fin Of Fear
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Nate Bryan, July 2012

content.description:
A massive sharp tipped "fin" with a very broad base sits on a solid perch about 3/4 of the way up the line.

Pitch #1: Really fun lay backing or hand jams up a wide crack (plenty of smaller protection options on both sides) leads to the scary looking fin. It would not even budge for me...I can't really envision it leaving its perch, but it is still quite daunting and exciting to climb past it. You can completely avoid it by climbing thin fun moves to the right. A few more face moves up lichen splattered rock leads to a two-bolt belay. 5.8, 20m.

Rappel the route. Consider rappelling to the left of the Fin if you get the same concerns as we did? I know I will do this route again and again.
content.protection: Set of Camalots and Nuts. Don't forget to bring maybe doubles on #4 Camalots? One is probably enough for most.
content.location:
This is located about 2m to the right of the Fret Arête. A bolted belay allows descending the route.

Be careful in the boulder fields ascending or descending and keep your time passing through the girl scout camp to a minimum, please!
